Tokyo Xtreme Racer is a great revival to form of a racing series that hit its stride in the PS2 era of arcade racing games. Genki have kept it simple, relatively clean, and lots of fun. The simcade aspect also makes the racing feel somewhat realistic unlike other arcade titles, and you can spend a lot of time fine-tuning the settings of each car as well. The performance and graphics isn't bad either, especially given this is on UE5.

It does lack a bit of polish, what with the somewhat unbalanced endgame rivals, uneven power upgrade balancing, AI that will corner at some incredible speeds, rendering of certain stickers and emblems... but Genki has done updates to try and fix these issues. They've also continued to add new free DLC content with the vtuber wanderers, so there seems to be a pipeline in place for more in the future. (Personally I'm hoping for WandereRyS, but we'll see)

Anyways, it's pretty solid and definitely worth it on sale if the $50 price is too high. You can get 25 to 30 hours of gameplay out of TXR easily if not more.

Great classic racing game! I love music and night races atmosphere here, really appreciate classic JDM cars even with those K cars and stuff. And car effects look absolutely stunning< I would even buy DLC just to see more of them. And the simple and intersting duel's on the road with skill tree was pretty nice. 

In fact, I've been waiting for the release of the game "NIGHT-RUNNERS" for quite a long time, so much so that I didn't even notice the release of this masterpiece at the time. Platinum was pretty tough and gameplay's a bit grindy, but I mostly like it. Ten devilish Z's out of ten.

Here is the review I wish I had seen before buying: I was worried that the highway-only format would be repetitive/boring but it's actually perfect. 

The world still feels super huge and open and would probably be annoying or doing too much with urban/city streets. It's super fun to cruise around chasing down rivals and grinding to tune your car or buy new cars. 

At certain points the game feels easy but as you level up it gets hard again and if you play on challenge mode (highly recommended) there is a lot to work towards which is very rewarding.

I was also worried about the lack of multiplayer but tbh it's really refreshing to just chill on my own and not worry about cheaters, server issues, or constant cosmetic upselling. I put 6 hours straight in my first single sitting playthrough if that tells you anything. 

Only things I would change is I think car sounds could be better. Music is basic and retro but repetitive and kinda puts you in a trance state  so maybe add a bit more variety. Maybe higher difficulty settings (already challenging enough but gets grindy at times) and maybe a multiplayer mode where we can all just spawn in on random parts of the highway, basically the same as NPCs against each other on small servers or something. But this game is honestly fine without multiplayer, really good as it is.

I'ts also really nice to play a game that just works and is actually in a finished state upon official release. It feels like a total package. Legitimate 9.5/10 game.

The difficulty is tuned just right for me, but your mileage may vary- if you aren't attentive to your own tuning or your opponent's upgrades, you might feel over or underpowered in comparison. 

Genki are also very good to the playerbase and constantly improving on things, from Early Access till now. It's seriously impressive how they made such a comeback after their long absence in the gaming space, and I think things can only go up from here.

TL;DR if you're gonna buy any racing game from this year, probably prioritize this.



Wow. Okay.

This is probably my favorite modern racing game so far.


Story-wise, it has a very solid foundation. They even built the story quite well, although if I may call it as it is, the cutscenes (a.k.a. poems, apparently) are a little too sappy. It reeeeally doesn't need the extra cutscene in my opinion, but maybe it's just an artistic choice.

Either way, the story was very enjoyable and easily understood. It's refreshing to see a racing game with so many deeply rooted lore (going back to almost 25 years ago) to ACTUALLY use the story as-is, with minimal retconning.

I really loved the inclusion of so many racers from older games (spoilers for some of the TXR entries, including this one), such as [spoiler]Purple Meteor, the original Jintei and Snake Eyes, and last but not least — a mainstay for maybe any game set in the Wangan/C1 area — Akio Asakura.[/spoiler]


Gameplay is very fun and engaging, especially in the earlier stages where you have to "make do" with whatever car you got at that point. You REALLY have to win, no matter what the strat may be.

One thing to point out is definitely, DEFINITELY disable camera shake. Or at least, minimise it. On lower speeds (100-200KM/H) it might look cool (although a little disturbing), but eventually in the higher speeds, you're gonna feel veeeery dizzy if you don't disable it.

On an unrelated note, the flashing streetlights makes me sleepy on high speeds, for some reason. Maybe I can make a scientific paper on it?


This game really plays out like it's older counterparts, just with more QoL that makes it more accessible without ruining the trademark pacing of TXR installations in general.



Graphics is — surprisingly — well made and quite nicely optimized (although I wouldn't call it 'light', per se), unlike some of the other Unreal Engine slop games out there that only flips assets and calls it a day. No. This isn't a game like that.

Although I still have to retweak some of the settings to get a consistent framerate in 1440p with a midrange PC, I still think that the optimisation deserves more recognisation due to the low, low bar being set by other UEslop games. To make a game that really captures the essential vibe of Tokyo, WHILE keeping it modern AND playable for midrange PCs? That's some baller move, I can't even lie.


Despite its steep price ($50), this game is a huge gust of fresh air to the racing game community, and I think is well worth the money. At least in my experience, I enjoyed this game much, much more than the Forza Horizon titles (despite spending almost 1000 hours on both games combined), The Crew 2, and the 2 modern Need For Speed titles I have in my library combined.

The past 70~ hours I spent with this game is of better quality than the 1000+ hours I've had with the other racing games in my steam library. Go figure.

If you care about handling feel, I would recommend playing a different racing game. Almost any other racing game. Maybe one of the old TXR games - I love TXR Drift 2 - but not this one.
I was willing to give the game a lot of leeway, given it was an Early Access release to improve on, but there hasn't been any notable improvement in the actual gameplay. New cars were added, and rivals are more balanced and dynamic, which is terrific!
But the driving model has not been improved, at all. The camera uncomfortably lurches with every input, uncoupled from the direction of the car, and even the car itself handles with a eerie delay. There is an inherent self-centering here that goes beyond understeer - it is extremely difficult to get your car to actually respond to any sort of left/right input. The game handles more like inputs apply forces to the car's body, which are then resisted by the suspension, rather than actually turning the wheels.
This all makes for a deeply unsettling experience if you're trying to do anything but pound down straights, and although I can play countless hours of Assetto Corsa or Richard Burns Rally in VR, here even playing on a monitor gives me a special kind of motion sickness. There's no amount of tuning that fixes these discomforts - I could only mitigate handling issues slightly - and there are no options to adjust steering sensitivity, lock the camera to the car, or almost anything else. There is also no cockpit view, which might have helped mitigate camera sway by giving a solid frame of reference.
Ultimately, if you just want to out-power opponents, admire 3D models of JDM classics, and play with customization and stickers - it's fine, but it feels worse to [i]play[/i] than almost anything else on the market. I'm not going to bother complaining about the lack of content variety - you either want to do nothing but run the highway loop, or you don't, that's all this game is - but even doing that never felt "right."

As a fan of the original PS2 versions of the TXR series including Drift and Racer. I cant help but feel underwhelmed by the "full release" of this game. My major gripes are as follows, The AI rubberbands and has 0 awareness of the player, Meaning they will ram you off the road and try to pit maneuver you. The Story while semi interesting is present through loading screens with a shimmering bubble effect on the text that almost feels like it was made in Microsoft Powerpoint. While this was acceptable on the ps2 in the modern age it seems rather poorly presented. There is No Gauge customization, which was present in TXR III you can enable Oil and Cooling settings but there is no upgrades to manage this like previous TXR's. There is no Yaseu Route, Shibuya/Shinjuku Routes or Ikebukuro routes. No Nagoya, No Osaka, In turn it feels pretty samey in alot of areas as most of us have driven this exact route of the Tokyo Expressway in many games. The Music is Weak and repetitive but that was never a strong suit of this series. The car list. This is the most insulting part of the game, I don't know if they failed at achieving the rights to alot of cars but there are some Serious ommision's from this game, No FD Civic, No Evo 8/9, No Eclipse 99/02, No Mistsuibishi FTO, No Base model Skylines, No GM cars, No Ford, No Dodge, No Lotus, No Gemballa/Porsche these were all present in previous releases of TXR just to name a few. The Handling is pretty mediocre, Its floaty and feels unresponsive. The Sound effects are a huge step backwards from modern racing games, These cars unfortunately sound like vacuum cleaners and are relatively really quiet compared to the other SFX in this game. While I really wanted to love this game, I love that it exists and serious props to Genki for a return to form with this series, However these are my biggest complaints and I will happily change my review positive if some or all of these issues are addressed in future updates but as it stands I'm underwhelmed. I've waited so long, Unfortunately this still seems like its missing a bulk of what this game COULD be.

I loved this game in its early access version but unless i'm missing something the game afterwards is just spamming nitrous against a very glitchy and advantaged AI. They can accelerate faster than you, bounce off walls without slowing down, and pull turns at impossible speeds. It takes all the fun out of the game when I literally have no chance without nitrous with a fully upgraded car.

I don't have the nostalgia factor, so I'm just gonna draw the conclusion from a fresh player perspective on this game as a stand alone piece, not as a 'successor to a classic franchise'

For the amount of car customisation and collection factor, it is pretty good. Maybe not the asking price level of good, but could be worth it on sale. 

For a pure racing gaming perspective, not worth it at all. This is not a very good racing game. The driving feels distinctively 'model car on a slotted track'. Add to that, pretty much all rival cars cheat, and the rubber banding is pretty excessive. You can get the exact same car with the exact same stats as the car a boss is driving, and the boss car is just going to be plain faster than you are. A lot faster than you are. The way late game bosses zip around corners is basically physics defying. Luckily they are not actually all that good at driving, so they crash into traffic a lot. Overall there is simply not very much driving skill involved, you either win by having a faster car, or you win by the NPCs crashing spectacularly.

To be honest, if I had knew this game's driving is like this, I wouldn't have bought it full price. And if I knew the game's balancing and grind is this bad in early game, I would have requested for a refund. Unfortunately by the time the excessive rubber banding and bots cheating driving physics becomes obvious, you are likely well beyond 2 hours of play time.

The game is also overly grindy. One of my main enjoyment is to collect cars and modify them, plus the game have a lot of opponents that require you to have specific cars to race them, so you will have to buy a lot of different cars. The game only rewards you handsomely for the first time defeating an opponent. Once you are buying and tuning your third or forth car, or preparing a car specifically for a rival, the BP you get from those first wins is simply not enough, and you will have to start repeatedly battle rivals on the road to grind for it. Battling rivals you have already defeated gives very little BP rewards compared to the amount you would need to collect multiple cars, including the special boss cars. This grinding process is extremely boring and time consuming, due to the low reward and the lack of driving skills involved in this game.

I would say this game is still worth a try just for the cars available, but wait for significant discounts.

I did not play the earlier games so I do not have the benefit of nostalgia like others. I think it is okay. But every race is either easily won or an absolute nightmare that requires you to cheese. The few races that are competitive are good. 

AI opponents break the laws of physics. You are punished for things they are not. They can knock you around but not the other way around. They go through corners without losing speed while you cannot. They hit walls or npc cars and lose no speed nor the amount of health that you do for the same. Insane rubberbanding. 

Game looks good but there is a lot lacking. Every night feels the same. Same skybox, same npc cars all driving exactly the same. Not much in terms of atmosphere. The map is big but it feels like 95% takes place in the inner loop so what is the point. Livery editor is needlessly restrictive and hard to use. 

Not bad, but I would not buy it again, especially full price. 6/10.
